A New Innovation in Online Courses
BYU-Idaho is offering an Institute-online hybrid course to all its students, in hopes that many students will choose this type of course with its gathering component over a purely online course.  Such courses can be a blessing both to the students who take them and the Institutes those students attend.

Online Convenience with the Benefits of Gathering
Hybrid courses are very similar to typical online courses, with one significant exception: about one third of the usual course work for the online course is replaced with the requirement that students attend at least 80% percent of the classes for the relevant Institute course.  While the standard semester schedule of most Institutes will not perfectly overlap with BYU-Idaho's unique semester schedule, in most cases dedicated students will be able to attend a sufficient number of classes during the months they are home from BYU-Idaho.

Winter semester 2013 offerings include:
  • FDREL 211 New Testament (1st half), section 31
  • FDREL 212 New Testament (2nd half), section 19
  • FDREL 121 Book of Mormon (1st half), section 82
  • FDREL 122 Book of Mormon (2nd half), section 86
  • FDREL 324 Doctrine and Covenants (1st half), section 21
  • FDREL 325 Doctrine and Covenants (2nd half), section 22
  • FDREL 301 Old Testament (1st half), section 18
  • FDREL 302 Old Testament (2nd half), section 9
Important Things to Note:
  • Students are permitted to take only one religion course per semester for BYU-Idaho credit.
  • Most traditional BYU-Idaho students will still earn the vast majority of their religion credits on BYU-Idaho's campus.  However, through hybrid courses many BYU-Idaho students may discover the blessings of attending Institute, while earning credit for one or two courses
  • Current offerings are limited. However, more courses will be offered in the future.
For more information about Institute-online hybrid courses visit https://www.byui.edu/online/courses/institute-hybrid-courses
